text: Could you explain to an idiot how calibration plots are useful?

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: Could you explain to an idiot how calibration plots are useful?

text: If you plot a line and see that implied probabilities based on odds offered don’t line up with actual frequencies, that could be an opportunity.

elements.text: If you plot a line and see that implied probabilities based on odds offered
don’t
line up with actual frequencies, that could be an opportunity.

text: If you were able to back or lay something at even money (2.0), and you noticed it actually only happened 42% of the time, what would you do about that? What if it won 56% of the time? What if 1.01 chances only came in 985 times out of a 1000 occurrences?

elements.text: If you were able to back or lay something at even money (2.0), and you noticed it actually only happened 42% of the time, what would you do about that? What if it won 56% of the time? What if 1.01 chances only came in 985 times out of a 1000 occurrences?

text: Another angle: let’s suppose you have a fundamental model that spits out probabilities you think are better than the market in certain situations. Calibration plots let you quickly eyeball if you’re right or not. If nothing else, the alpha is not letting your own BS doom you into a trap of a massive leak.

text: The thing is, if you don't hedge, your EV is just an estimate of the true EV. I've seen models that beat or underperform the EV to a significant degree (where BSP is used as the proxy for it).

text: The EV Vs BSP chart isn't very useful, you know that generally bsp is close to 0 bsp so ofc you're gonna see loss if you don't beat bsp.
